Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: The standard P2P process usually goes like this: Create Purchase Requisition, Approve it, Issue Purchase Order, Receive Goods, then Vendor Invoice Received, Match Invoice to PO, Release Payment, and finally Close Case. So I should check each case to see if the order of activities follows this sequence.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Starting with Case 1001. The activities are in the correct order: Create, Approve, Issue PO, Receive Goods, Invoice Received, Match, Release Payment, Close. That seems normal. No issues here.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Now Case 1002. Lets check the order. It starts with Create, then Issue PO before Approve. Thats a problem. Normally, the Purchase Requisition needs to be approved before issuing a Purchase Order. So in Case 1002, the Purchase Order was issued before approval. Thats an anomaly.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Why is that problematic? Because the approval step is a necessary check to ensure the purchase is authorized. Issuing a PO without approval could lead to unauthorized spending or purchases that arent approved, which might be a risk.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Next, Case 1003. The activities are Create, Approve, Issue PO, then Release Payment before receiving goods. Wait, thats not right. The standard flow is to receive goods before releasing payment. So in Case 1003, the payment was released before the goods were received. Thats a problem.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Because you cant pay for goods you havent received yet. This might indicate that the company is paying before the goods arrive, which could be a risk of non delivery or fraud.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 1004. Lets check. Create, Approve, Receive Goods, then Issue PO. Wait, thats not correct. The Purchase Order should be issued after the requisition is approved, not after receiving goods. So in Case 1004, the Purchase Order was issued after receiving the goods. Thats an anomaly.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Wait, but in Case 1004, the order is: Create, Approve, Receive Goods, Issue PO, then Vendor Invoice Received, Match, Release Payment, Close. Thats not right. The PO should be issued before receiving the goods. So receiving the goods before the PO is issued is a problem.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Maybe the company received the goods without going through the proper procurement process, which could be a red flag.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: So the anomalies are: Case 1002: Issue PO before approval. Case 1003: Release payment before receiving goods. Case 1004: Issue PO after receiving goods.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - NE
Text: I should check if there are any other anomalies. For example, in Case 1003, the Vendor Invoice Received is after the Release Payment. Wait, thats not correct. The invoice should be received before matching to the PO, and then payment is released. So in Case 1003, the invoice is received after the payment is released. Thats another problem.

Name: Backtracking - PE
Text: Wait, no, looking back: Case 1003: ... So the order is: Create, Approve, Issue PO, then Release Payment, then Vendor Invoice Received, then Receive Goods, then Match, then Close.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Thats a problem because the invoice was received before the goods were received. Normally, the invoice is received after the goods are received, or at least after the PO is issued. But in this case, the invoice is received before the goods are received. Thats not correct.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: So thats another anomaly in Case 1003. So thats two anomalies in Case 1003: releasing payment before receiving goods, and receiving invoice before receiving goods.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: So in summary, the anomalies are: Case 1002: Issue PO before approval. Case 1003: Release payment before receiving goods, and receive invoice before receiving goods. Case 1004: Issue PO after receiving goods.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: So these are the three cases with anomalies. Each of these steps is out of order and could lead to problems like unauthorized purchases, paying for goods not received, or processing invoices before the goods are actually received.
